title: Add async-nats crate
body:
### Background

The NATS client offers two kinds of APIs: blocking and asynchronous. The latest version of `nats` published on crates.io has an implementation written in async style, and the blocking API simply wraps the async API with `block_on(...)` calls.

We experienced difficulties maintaining that codebase due to instability of async Rust, general friction of writing code in async style, and hidden performance costs. Then we removed async code from the guts of the client. The current master branch contains a client written in good old sync style with a blocking API. However, the async API is missing.

### Implementation

This PR brings the async API back, which is now just a wrapper around the sync API. We use `unblock(...)` from the `blocking` crate to make functions asynchronous. Note that `unblock()` "cheats" by running code on a separate thread pool (think of it as syscall threads in the Go runtime), which is okay for functions that aren't performance sensitive (e.g. `connect()`).

However, functions like `publish()` and `next()` must be faster than that. Async `publish()` attempts to write the whole message into the buffered TCP/TLS stream in a non-blocking way. If the message doesn't fit in the buffer, we use `unblock()`. Async `next()` will first try to get the next buffered message without blocking or fall back to `unblock()`. Note that this can be optimized further in follow-up PRs, but benchmark already show performance comparable to the previous pure async implementation.

### Crate organization

@spacejam and I figured it'd be nicer to have two crates: `nats` and `async-nats` that look exactly the same except one is sync and the other is async. For example, `nats::connect(url)` becomes `async_nats::connect(url).await` when you write in async style. This PR introduces the new crate `async-nats`.

Previously we had the async API inside the `nats::asynk` module. That worked fine but the API organization wasn't as clean: `nats::connect(url)` would map to `nats::asynk::connect(url).await` but then we also had `nats::Options::new().connect(url)` that maps `nats::Options::new().connect_async(url).await`. That API didn't feel very consistent.

### Benchmarks

On my machine:

| Client | Command | Mb/sec |
|--------|---------|--------|
| Go (multithreaded) | `nats-bench -n 10000000 test` | 840 |
| Go (singlethreaded) | `GOMAXPROCS=1 nats-bench -n 10000000 test` | 990 |
| Rust (old sync) | `cargo run --release --example nats_bench test -n 10000000` | 550 |
| Rust (new sync) | `cargo run --release --example nats_bench test -n 10000000` | 900 |
| Rust (new async) | `cargo run --release --example async_nats_bench test -n 10000000` | 560 |

title: Synchronous client implementation
body:
Previously, the core client implementation was written in async style, and then the sync API was layered on top of it. Async Rust has non-negligible costs when it comes to compilation times and code maintenance. Given how much the async library ecosystem is in still in flux (and for how long it has been), maintaining crates outside the scope of this NATS client and constantly upgrading dependencies is becoming untenable.

This PR simplifies the core client implementation so that it's written in traditional sync style. The async API is presently gone but I will soon add it in a separate PR - it'll just be an adapter on top of the sync client. This way users of sync Rust don't have to bring in numerous async dependencies (improving compilation times) and code maintenance will be simpler.

title: Make test server accept non-blocking
body:
Being in blocking mode initially meant that a server with no clients at the end of a test would be stuck waiting for clients and wouldn't read the shutdown flag - meaning the test couldn't complete.

This makes the `TCPListener` always non-blocking.

title: Cut new test server release
body: cc @platy

title: Test server changes to improve usage in tests
body:
* Added readme to explain usage
* Wildcard support for subscriptions
* RAII to automatically shutdown server after use
* Default to use of automatic port assignment

title: Add Options::with_jwt()
body: This is the equivalent of `Options.UserJwt` in Go: https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/nats-io/nats.go#UserJWT

title: Configuring client cert and private key
body:
This PR adds new method `Options::client_cert()` that configures client certificate and private key.

I also replaced `webpki` with `rustls-native-certs` so that instead of loading a static set of root certificates, we load certificates installed on the system. While playing with authentication options I was expecting `nats` to recognize my locally installed certificates by itself, which was previously not the case.

Closes #104

title: Shutdown when the last reference to Connection is dropped
body: Fixes #118

title: Flush before dropping the connection
body:
Discussed this with @derekcollison - I'm proposing a simple solution here. Changes:

1. When `nats::Connection` is dropped, we flush (and wait for the flush to complete).
2. When `nats::asynk::Connection` is dropped, we let the client thread asynchronously flush (but we don't wait for it).

cc @andrewbanchich

title: Correct crate name in issue template
body: Corrects crate name in grep command.

title: Update dependencies
body: Closes #111

title: Fix connection leak
body:
This problem was reported by @dontlaugh on Slack (#rust channel),

The issue is that dropping `Connection` does not trigger thread shutdown, so if you drop it without calling `.close().await` on it, the thread simply keeps running and therefore keeps holding an active NATS connection.

The solution is to signal to the thread that it must shutdown when `Connection` is dropped.

title: Implement missing options
body:
disconnect_callback
reconnect_callback
reconnect_delay_callback
max_reconnects
close_callback

[WIP]

I'm a bit confused about what max_reconnects is meant to be:
> /// Set the maximum number of reconnect attempts.
> /// If no servers remain that are under this threshold,
> /// all servers will still be attempted.
Isn't this conflicting, saying if no server remains under the max attempts, then connect anyway... ?

I'm not sure how to implement the close_callback for the drain/close situation because the client dispatch where we wait for op's does not seem to have "visibility" over the close.

title: Attempt to fix TLS
body: This is just a test right now - I changed `async-tls` to `async-rustls`.

title: Vectorize logo
body:
- 12x smaller memory footprint
- Scales horizontally

title: Remove crossbeam-channel from the public API
body:
We're not using `crossbeam-channel` anywhere, and yet there were some remnants of it our public API. I'm removing those and also removing `const` annotations on some functions that are not really useful (they may only be useful on *constructors*, perhaps).

I'm planning to further clean up the API after the next release.

title: Update smol
body:
This PR updates `smol` to v1.0 and replaces `serde` with `json`.

Compilation times are cut roughly in half on my 8-core machine, which means a debug build now takes 27 seconds. There are still ways to go, but it seems that the largest part of compilation is related to crypto stuff (`nkeys` and `async-tls`), which will be difficult to trim down. `smol` itself takes up only around 5 seconds.

title: Add respond on asynk::Message
body:
This is the same function that exists on the sync part but on the async one

Fixes #96

title: Fix Mutex usage in asynk::client::cleanup_subscriptions function.
body:
Fix mutex usage for https://github.com/nats-io/nats.rs/issues/92 

MutexGuard for unsubscribed list was captured by for loop context.

title: Add NKey authentication
body: This PR adds a new authentication method: `Options::with_nkey()`.

title: Make the asynk module public
body:
This PR finally exposes the long-awaited async interface for the NATS client. :)

Will publish a new version of the crate when this PR gets merged.

title: Prepare v0.7.2 for release
body: This release includes #88

title: Fix unsubscription
body:
Previously, `Subscription::unsubscribe()` and `Subscription::close()` were doing nothing. This PR adds the missing logic - the subscription gets recorded in the `unsubscribed` set denoting dead subscriptions for which we haven't sent UNSUB yet. Eventually, `cleanup_subscriptions()` will be called that collects dead subscriptions and sends UNSUB to the server.

Closes #82

title: Update smol dependency
body: This updates smol from v0.1 to v0.3. At the same time, we remove most of the usage of the `futures` crate.
